questions.question: 1. Which of the following is not an array?

explanations.a: All the elements are of the same type (integer).
explanations.b: This option contains a mix of different types such as strings and boolean values.
explanations.d: All the elements are boolean values.

questions.question: 2. Which of the following is an array sorted in descending order?

explanations.a: -8 and -17 must be swapped as -8 > -17 and -14 > -17.
explanations.b: This array is in ascending order. It must be reversed to be the correct answer.
explanations.d: This sequence is in descending order.

questions.question:
3. Consider the following arrays:
A = [5, -5, 10, 1]
B = [0, 100, 1, 0]
Which of the following arrays represents the combination of the 2 arrays in a sorted order(assume ascending order)?

explanations.a: This answer simply involves combining the two arrays one after the other (here B after A). This array is not sorted in ascending order.
explanations.b: This answer simply involves combining the two arrays one after the other (here A after B). This array is not sorted in ascending order.
explanations.c: -5 must come right at the beginning of the array as -5 < 0 and -5 < 1.
explanations.d: This array is the right combination of the two arrays in ascending order as all elements are present from both the arrays in a sorted order.

questions.question: 4. When dividing an array into equal-sized partitions (as closely as possible), how does the number of partitioning rounds/iterations required vary with the number of partitions made per step (fixed number per step)? Note that the number of partitions directly affects the size of the partitions. Greater the number of partitions, the smaller each partition will be.

answers.a: Does not vary, i.e, is independent of the number of partitions made per step
answers.c: Is inversely proportional, i.e., the number of partitioning rounds/iterations decreases with an increase in the number of partitions being made per step
answers.d: Is directly proportional, i.e., the number of partitioning rounds/iterations increases with an increase in the number of partitions being made per step

explanations.a: There is a correlation between the two, i.e, changing the number of partitions does affect the number of partitioning rounds.
explanations.b: The correlation between the two is fixed and does not vary with the array or any other factors, i.e, is independent of the situation.
explanations.c: When you increase the number of partitions made per step, each partitioning round reduces the size of the partitions more significantly. As a result, fewer partitioning rounds/iterations are required to reach the base case where each partition contains a single element or a small number of elements.
explanations.d: The correlation is not direct. Increasing the number of partitions made per steps leads to a decrease in the number of partitioning rounds/iterations.
